evidence.text: The panel held that based on the record in this case, the district court did not err by finding plaintiffs satisfied the requirements of Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a) such that a class could be certified under Rule 23(b)(2).

extracted.value: Affirmed class certification under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2) for involuntary homeless persons, finding district court properly satisfied Rule 23(a) requirements.

evidence.text: Addressing the merits, the panel affirmed the district court’s ruling that the City of Grants Pass could not, consistent with the Eighth Amendment, enforce its anti-camping ordinances against homeless persons for the mere act of sleeping outside with rudimentary protection from the elements, or for sleeping in their car at night, when there was no other place in the City for them to go.

extracted.value: Affirmed district court's ruling that City of Grants Pass cannot enforce anti-camping ordinances against homeless persons for sleeping outside with rudimentary protection when no shelter is available, as it violates the Eighth Amendment.

evidence.text: The death of class representative Debra Blake while the matter was on appeal did not moot the class’s claims as to all challenged ordinances except possibly the anti-sleeping ordinance. The panel vacated the summary judgment as to that ordinance and remanded to allow the district court the opportunity to substitute a class representative in Blake’s stead.

extracted.value: Vacated summary judgment as to anti-sleeping ordinance and remanded for substitution of class representative following death of Debra Blake.

evidence.text: The panel directed the district court on remand to narrow its injunction to enjoin only those portions of the anti-camping ordinances that prohibited conduct protected by Martin and this opinion.

extracted.value: Directed district court to narrow injunction to enjoin only portions of anti-camping ordinances prohibiting conduct protected by Martin and this opinion.
